body:
```
[trickle] No significant performance differences
```

Since I'm out next week... I'm going to set a reviewer list for this, and leave some notes.

Reviewers: please wait for Yash to signal this is ready. Treat this with high priority: it's a big change and it's better to get it through then to send it into a long maintenance spiral. If there's a day or two of trailing work for a few people it'll be better than burning Yash's time for a month.

That said, this has some deep ramifications for wrapped language builds, and not everything is explicitly tested for PRs. I'd like to see sign off that the above standard should hold from @jtattermusch  @nathanielmanistaatgoogle  @murgatroid99  @kpayson64  @stanley-cheung  @nicolasnoble  and @apolcyn  before this is submitted. Yash, feel empowered to stand at folks desks to remind to check that, but do wait for it.

@dgquintas and @markdroth  please give this a once over for code within core. Hold the standard of will it work - and feel free to give Yash a list of cleanup to do post submission to make it good.

Okay, I'll bite: is this being done as incrementally as possible? Is this the smallest pull request that can be made, with more of the feature to come in future small pull requests?

(On the other hand: congratulations on reaching another milestone on what's clearly a long journey.)

Yeah, this is the pretty close to the smallest change that makes sense....
its also the noticeable hump that we need to cross to get back to small
changes. Which is the reason I'm encouraging post-PR cleanup instead of
review bikeshedding. It would be easy to turn this into a not small change.

On Thu, Sep 21, 2017 at 9:20 PM Nathaniel Manista <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Okay, I'll bite: is this being done as incrementally as possible? Is this
> the smallest pull request that can be made, with more of the feature to
> come in future small pull requests?
>
> (On the other hand: congratulations on reaching another milestone on
> what's clearly a long journey.)
>
> â€”
> You are receiving this because your review was requested.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/12692#issuecomment-331346212>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AJpudRAPLOajVrTUtBswksa0pSlG73Phks5skzWfgaJpZM4PgLcC>
> .
>
Okay. Glad I asked.

There are some changes that I can carve out into small PRs. (I actually based this PR on top of PR #12654). But most of the changes are uninteresting. They would follow one of these patterns -
- Explicit pointer conversions to avoid C++ conversion errors
- Adding extern "C" to allow for compatibility with C files. (These are mostly because of references from test/core which are still C. Those can also be changed to C++, but I was getting incremental errors with those, so I decided to make the switch for src/core first.)
- Changing declaration/initialization position of variables to avoid errors of the type - jumps crossing initialization
- Other
The 'Other' changes would be most interesting to watch out for. These would be changes in build.yaml, tools, templates, etc. I might have actually missed some of them. (I just remembered one while typing this)

```
[trickle] No significant performance differences
```

assessment: if we expect it's within a few days of work to repair
artifacts, its better to accept breakage and clean up.

*[build.yaml, line 42 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/12692#-KuuAP2YvRyDb6B5f-2w:-KuuAP2YvRyDb6B5f-2x:bw7n6qs) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/f5b2347f5fd2fbace3be8dd84ef76abc212796c0/build.yaml#L42)):*

Don't we need to make these same changes in the BUILD files?

---

*[src/core/ext/census/gen/census.pb.cc, line 0 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/12692#-KuuFcOQDOq6n2wLj8p2:-KuuFcOQDOq6n2wLj8p3:b-slwfzk) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/f5b2347f5fd2fbace3be8dd84ef76abc212796c0/src/core/ext/census/gen/census.pb.cc#L0)):*
Is this file also generated by nanopb?  If so, it may have the same issue that we have with the load_balancer.pb.cc file (see my comment there).

---

*[src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/lb_policy/grpclb/proto/grpc/lb/v1/load_balancer.pb.cc, line 0 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/12692#-KuuFNJ9p-b1qeYdOEYt:-KuuFNJ9p-b1qeYdOEYu:b-ee5vup) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/f5b2347f5fd2fbace3be8dd84ef76abc212796c0/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/lb_policy/grpclb/proto/grpc/lb/v1/load_balancer.pb.cc#L0)):*
This file is actually generated by nanopb and will be generated with a `.c` suffix.  And I think we have a script that checks to see if it's generated correctly.  Have we ensured that we're not going to break any of that?

---

*[src/core/ext/transport/chttp2/client/secure/secure_channel_create.cc, line 168 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/12692#-KuuGi35b1im1jQp57x1:-KuuGi35b1im1jQp57x2:b-y2zcrm) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/f5b2347f5fd2fbace3be8dd84ef76abc212796c0/src/core/ext/transport/chttp2/client/secure/secure_channel_create.cc#L168)):*
> ```cpp
>   }
>   // Add channel arg containing the server URI.
>   grpc_arg arg = grpc_channel_arg_string_create(
> ```

As I mentioned in one of the other PRs, I'd really like to see the `grpc_channel_arg_*_create()` functions changed to expect a `const char*` as the argument, so that we don't need a cast in every call (and I would like to see all the casts that you've already added removed).  But I guess we can do this as a separate PR if you'd prefer.

---

*[src/core/tsi/fake_transport_security.cc, line 101 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/12692#-KuuUjH71hCJF6_zFQnd:-KuuUjH71hCJF6_zFQne:b-uz1nwy) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/f5b2347f5fd2fbace3be8dd84ef76abc212796c0/src/core/tsi/fake_transport_security.cc#L101)):*
> ```cpp
> static tsi_result tsi_fake_handshake_message_from_string(
>     const char *msg_string, tsi_fake_handshake_message *msg) {
>   int i;
> ```

Nit: Can declare this inside of the for loop on the next line.

Previously, markdroth (Mark D. Roth) wroteâ€¦
As I mentioned in one of the other PRs, I'd really like to see the `grpc_channel_arg_*_create()` functions changed to expect a `const char*` as the argument, so that we don't need a cast in every call (and I would like to see all the casts that you've already added removed). But I guess we can do this as a separate PR if you'd prefer.
grpc_arg stores it as a char * and I didn't want to change that field to a const char * because there was a place where it needed to be used as a char *. It just seemed cleaner at that point to force all calls to grpc_channel_arg_*_create to explicitly cast it. I can change this in a separate PR later if you feel strongly about this. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/12692)*

grpc_arg stores it as a char * and I didn't want to change that field to a const char * because there was a place where it needed to be used as a char *. It just seemed cleaner at that point to force all calls to grpc_channel_arg_*_create to explicitly cast it. I can change this in a separate PR later if you feel strongly about this.
I am not suggesting changing `grpc_arg` (although if there's only one place that uses it as non-const, that may be a good idea too). All I'm suggesting is to change the `grpc_channel_arg_*_create()` functions to take a `const` argument. That way, the cast is only needed inside of those three functions instead of having to be done at every call site. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/12692)*
